config.question: What differentiated the Spanish from the colonists in the British backcountry in America?

choices.content: Unlike the English colonists, the Spanish exploited Native American labor and reduced entire Indian villages to servitude.
Most of the British backcountry settlers were soldiers, whereas most of the Spanish were planters.
The English were motivated to convert Native Americans to Catholicism, while the Spanish tried to convert them to Anglicanism.
Unlike the British, the Spanish did not permit colonists to have relationships with Native American women.

answer_3.response: Consider This: The Indians belonged to the lowest social class in Spanish colonies. Many Indians moved to the Spanish towns, and although they lived alongside the Europeans—something rare in British America—they were consigned to the lowest social class, objects of European contempt. However much their material conditions changed, the southwestern Indians resisted efforts to convert them to Catholicism. See L.O. 4.1 What difficulties did Native Americans face in maintaining their cultural independence on the frontiers of English and Spanish settlement?
